values: This is how long my hair is now: I'll try to catch up...

I miss the sea
and the way it spoke to me
and the days it felt like
and ocean lived inside of me
the opposing tides
that formed a part of me
that roared and crashed
til I felt sure
my chest would burst
I miss the thrill
of diving in head first
of being swallowed whole
pushed and pulled
and weightless
caressed
by waves
standing up to an indomitable force
and looking over
the vast and endless
I miss feeling endless
unassailable and at peace
and the sting
of sun dried lips
and salt licked skin


I seem to be seriously lacking in productivity these past few days. The above was the best I could come up with as I was trying to write for a video I'm supposed to produce for class. There's only two weeks left. I finally bought my Christmas break plane ticket and two weeks from now I'll be in San Juan, with my family.

here is an article I enjoyed more than I thought I would:

J. CREW GETS ARTSIER By Roberta Smith
You never know when contemporary art is going to insinuate itself into a normally art-free zone. Last summer the blissfully mindless sanctuary of the J. Crew catalog was breached by photographs of the tall, suave painter Alex Katz in his studio, modeling J. Crew clothes.
Now the October J. Crew catalog has gone even further. Its menswear section includes pictures of seven New York artists wearing J. Crew shirts, sweaters and jackets and occasionally entire outfits, also in their studios, nearly all looking fabulously relaxed and rumpled.
Several generations are represented. At the young, relatively unknown end of the spectrum are the abstract painters Julien Smith and Chris Dorland. The mid-career slot is occupied by Ryan McGinness and Glenn Ligon. For artists of a certain age, we have the photographer Stephen Shore, the painter Billy Sullivan and the Conceptual pioneer Vito Acconci.
The biggest surprise is Mr. Acconci, a poet who became one of the stars of the late 1960s- early '70s Post-Minimalist underground, a generation that is generally revered in part because - except for Richard Serra and Brice Marden - most of them supposedly didn't make much money.
The irony is that much of Mr. Acconci's early work consists of dark, furtive photographs of him doing one weird, intensely personal thing or another, say, burning the hair off his chest and tucking his penis between his legs in an attempt to become a woman. In his famous 1971 performance titled "Seedbed," he spent hours masturbating under the floor at the Sonnabend Gallery in Soho.
Now Mr. Acconci, looking unusually scrubbed and combed, is shown in jeans and a mini-check shirt, crouched down by a table, squinting at a macquette as if he were imagining the siting of the full scale sculpture.
There's always a weird rush when you see people you know from one context suddenly pop up in another, as if it were the most natural thing in the world. And it is becoming increasingly natural. All kinds of visual artists have appeared in Gap ads over the years. Artists have modeled clothes in magazine fashion spreads. Jasper Johns has played the Cowardly Lion in a reenactment of "The Wizard of Oz" in Vogue. Furthermore, the last leader of the intact U.S.S.R. has lent his presence, comfortably cosseted in the back of a limousine, to ads for Louis Vuitton. After that, nothing should surprise.
Clearly we've come a long way since the early 1990s, when an emerging artist named Matthew Barney was excoriated for, among other things, having a J. Crew connection in his past. As a young nobody in the late 1980s, he had helped put himself through Yale working as a J. Crew model.
Artists are more a part of society than they were even in Mr. Barney's youth, and this is generally a good thing, especially for society. They are increasingly accepted as semi-ordinary people with potentially extraordinary contributions to make to our lives. Such acceptance has minor side effects, including appearances in J. Crew catalogs - not for money, but for fun, and probably a little publicity.
It would really be something if the creative types making these appearances weren't only men. To depart from the anonymous, impossibly thin, female ingénues who populate J. Crew catalogs might help change more than just the way we see artists._NYTimes

For the moment, until August 27, you can find me here:
ARTIST'S BLOG

... then what does an empty desk mean?

I found this pretty fantastic:


I am a bundle of nerves as of yesterday, I think.  It's the same feeling I get when I look at my room and realize I have let the mess get out of control and, even though I know I'm just exaggerating and being somewhat lazy, I look at it and think it's impossible to clean up so I just go to sleep instead.  Only I'm talking about my life for the next month or so:  This is my last casting job and I'm not sure Tere, my boss, realizes this.  It's a movie about Navy SEALs, the script is mostly action/chase/guns sequences.  We're still waiting on the producers/director to give us enough material to actually hold a casting.  Meanwhile I'm building extras books.  Except I haven't really gotten much done.
I also have less than two weeks left at La 8.  I feel like maybe I've been too busy with castings and surfshops to pay any real attention to getting prepared for my residency and the thought SCARES me.  Seriously, it does.
Yesterday I got an offer to write a fashion column for this online magazine , soon to come out in print as well.  Surfing related, of course.  It sounds like it could be a lot of fun but also very time consuming.  I would also be doing it from New York, which I'm not sure how it would work out, even though they do have surf shops over there.  I'm afraid if I say no I might lose my opportunity to do something that's always interested me but if I say yes I might be biting off more than I can chew.
Then again, two weeks or a month from now I won't be feeling the way I am today...
I guess maybe one thing at a time is not an option right now.  I can do this, I'm just being dramatic.

...in an article about the boom in the film industry.



that's right. 

I just noticed this photo is flipped (Photo Booth), oh well...

It doesn't matter because... It's time for an upgrade!
I can't be a photographer with an outdated digital camera.

Which is why I have just purchased this baby.

True it's not the top of professional grade cameras, actually, quite the opposite.  But it'll get the job done.  And I'm very excited about it.
7-11 days is too long to wait...

... visually, that is.



So I'm thinking I might film that short film this summer after all.  Why not, right?  The thing is the setting might have to be changed from Paris to Puerto Rico, making it a bit like a Rum Diary type of thing... only not.  I finally talked to Evan today, and he suggested the same thing.  Also, I'm IN LOVE with the beautiful, though sad, abandoned buildings in Ponce.  I'm going back for more photos.  Maybe some location scouting?
I have to talk to Omar about the animating the dream sequence again.  Beyond awesome would be if he could collaborate with Quique, which would really send the film over the top.  Did I mention I found my main actor? pics of him soon...

I wonder if I should try selling part of my book / dvd collection over the internet in order to make some extra cash over the summer.  It's not like I can take them with me.  An online garage sale! 
I'm sleepy... that is all.

Maybe it was the great, though short, conversation I had last night with a BEAUTIFUL boy who asked about what the concept behind my art is.  He's a friend of Mónica's I had met before but had never talked to because he has a girlfriend.  He doesn't know it yet, but he will be in one of my videos.
Maybe it's a bit of Eureka syndrome since I've been slacking a bit these past two days.  Mostly I've been cooking and playing with Photoshop, but it's given me time to think.  I have sort of pooled together all the advice I've gotten from Ana, from Sam, from the curator who chose me for the residency... and it's all been floating around in my thoughts.
What I'm getting to is: I think I've got it!  Though it might be too early to tell.  But today I finally got a very clear image in my mind of what I want my show to be.  I can see the space and the work in it.  It will include both interactive videos and photography.  Some details, like what exactly am I going to do about sound, are still fuzzy of course.  However I finally feel confident again.  
Since I can't give anymore details yet, I leave you with an image from last night...
p.s. Tengo un bajón SERIO de playa.  Quién se apunta? ;)

These here are my Grandfather's sunglasses from the 80s, found while cleaning out
Abuelita's apartment to rent.  Yes.  Ignore the fact that I look like a total hipster in this
photo, I am in love.
all i can think about...

Ana and the goats.



Goats are a lot more like dogs than one would think.



Awwwww
today the producer and the director of the film i'm working as a stand-in in were trying to convince me to go into acting.
taken last month at Sam's apt.
Ida Lupino

It was a bit nerve racking, standing in line for the register to buy the most decent cheap wine we could find for the event, not knowing if anyone would actually show.  What I didn't know was that, due to a couple more activities at the University (a play and a book presentation, I think), the wine would be completely gone halfway through the event.  The place was packed, actually.  It was a bit surreal, seeing all these people there.  
I was so happy to have friends and family there too.  Ana made it, though she refused to go near her pic! afraid of being recognized haha.  The people from the surf shop came, which I found incredibly sweet because I know it's not their scene.  Denisse came, though I'm still afraid she might have been expecting to find herself on the wall, but there simply wasn't any budget or space for it.  The professors were incredibly generous with their compliments.  The head of the department actually congratulated the group on "the best exhibit he's seen in years", mind you this was after a photo session for I don't know what magazine.  By this point our egos were HUGE, ha!
Camille was hilarious, taking me to a corner to "interview" me, her eyes shifty, trying to see who was watching.  She looked so legit that people actually said things like: "oh, I'm sorry to interrupt.  We'll take photos later."  After the interview she gave me some pointers, saying I should learn to stay away from the clichés when answering.  She was dead serious, this was meant to be practice for real interviews to come.  I love Camille.
The surprise was the director and assistant director from the commercial I did actually went.  I sent facebook invites, but did not expect them to actually show.  Tere, my castings boss, didn't.  I got an email from the assistant director, who will be directing his first feature soon and I'm up for a part, saying he really liked my art and would like to collaborate on something.
Camille - "you know he's hitting on you, right?"
Ida - "oh, of course."
Camille - "poor kid."
After that, dinner with the parents and the next day it was back to work.  Not bad at all for my very first show.  Up next I have two more group shows at the University: Noche de Arte Electrónico, which is less than two weeks away, and the graduate show, which is in May.  Then the residency and solo show in August.  Then relocate in September.  Suddenly it seems like someone pushed the fast forward button on my life, weird.  But I'm looking forward to it all.

Oh how I love the characters of New York City.  One of them was the professor whose class I sat in.  When she spoke of Andy Warhol she spoke of having visited The Factory.  She also had some very interesting thoughts on facebook and internet based art.  She suggested we look at writer William Gibson's  blog.  It's pretty interesting and the links he posts are awesome.  I think I might add a blog page to my portfolio site, while I'm working on my residency, something that deals solely with the creative process and the experience of being there, working, for one month.  I'm starting to get more used to the idea of it.  I'm still scared shitless, but I have a few ideas to start working on.  It's so hard to begin!  Especially when I have these other things to work on.  I think maybe I'll just start jotting down my ideas for now, and actually start working on them after April 16th, the date of Noche de Arte Electrónico, and then Circa... uf

I feel as though my mind has been invaded.  All my thoughts revolve around the upcoming exhibitions, SVA - NYC, and Camera Boy.

ps. yesterday was a great day.  Hopefully the pictures will come out and I'll post those soon.
Walking out of the apartment I had an overwhelming feeling that I was forgetting something.  I think maybe I just wasn't ready to leave.
ok, I know I need a new camera, that mine is obsolete... but this is too much

New Yorkers should expect a visitor next Wednesday afternoon...
and she'll be staying for a week.

OMG I totally sent an e-mail to the wrong person.  As in, I sent a personal e-mail, making fun of the way I applied for a job, to the person I sent the original application.  Ohhhhh, I don't feel so good...
It wasn't too bad, but still.

as soon as I got these I knew they needed to be documented.  I told Mónica and this is what she did:







On a similar note: I think maybe I've been living it up a little too much lately and it's about time to settle down again, a little bit.  New plan: work, work, work.  I'm going to get everything finished!!! Well, that's the plan at least.  I need to get out of here, soon.

today was a tough day...






... actually changed my mind, don't feel like writing about it.

there's always a bright side:  i'm up for a job as editor of a short film (mostly because the director apparently has a crush on me, but whatever)
and Camera Boy is still wonderful, so i have more to look forward to in NYC.  his text messages make me smile daily.

And a funny one of Jeffrey, my partner in crime.  There's definitely an overdue Jeffrey entry, but it'll have to wait until I'm not driving myself insane with this thing.

I am driving myself crazy at the moment with this project.  After a whole semester of working
on it, I still have no idea how to use Max/MSP.  I downloaded the 30 day trial thinking that I 
would be able to finish this thing at home.  So far my computer's on the verge of overheating,
as is my brain.  I'm simply not used to doing this alone.  I need help :(
Albis got me a Wacom for Christmas / belated birthday gift.  I still have no idea how to react.

what is going on with the world today?
ok, so it's just me... fuck

I am so very very tired...

and there is still much to do.
